But here's the issue, when you've got an agreement, when you've done everything right and you're following the laws of business, we expect the unions to follow the law, too. And we expect that when they have an agreement they come to work. And we had agreements. And these were deemed by the Fair Work Australia to be illegal, by the Federal Courts to be illegal and Julia Gillard put out a statement saying she thought they were illegal. So the point is, gee, it took us eight days to get people back to work in an illegal strike. The area we would like to focus on is, hey, once it's declared illegal, get back to work. These projects are big, big projects and they're massive and they cost a lot of money.

And so it's kind of like a situation where, gee, it's like a two-year torturous battle to go through courts to pay fines, I guess you would say, for being illegal. It should be a bit different we believe. Look, we play by the rules. We respect the workers. Like I said, we want to adequately compensate them. We want them to be safe on our projects. We just think it's a basic fairness and we are working for basic fairness.
So you pretty much would like to be able to – or to have immediate sort of sanctions for the illegal behavior?
Well, I think I'll let you draw conclusions to my comments.

Okay. And just one more actually had on Bayu-Undan or Sunrise. The graph you put on where you showed a few projects and they ticked various boxes, it seemed that the Darwin option ticked a lot more than the floating LNG. And is that a good indication of the way Woodside is thinking of the project?

Look, with due respect to my three partners who are really great and aligned, I promised that we wouldn't show any favoritism until we get to a unanimous agreement. So I am going to have to beg off that question.

Okay. Also, one more. The Alinta deal you mentioned, I know you said you could not talk about price but you referred to some recent WA gas deals. Is that maybe aligned with oil prices or is it set price? Is there anything at all you can give us like that?
No, I would just say that you can look up online some of the recent contracts. They are publicly stated. And, yeah, we like them.
Okay, thanks, Don.
Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately we have run out of time for any further questions. I would now like to hand the call back over to Don Voelte. Please go ahead.

Yeah, well thank you very much. I have got two announcements, one small one and one pretty large one for me. First off, with the changes in the tax laws you may see some of our managers including myself selling some of our shares. Now we all have been really good at keeping skin in the game but the new law says that when we get shares in we have to pay tax on them. And some of my guys are racking up some really big tax bills. They have got to eat and they have got to have houses and they have got to pay mortgages and they have got to send their kids to university.

So don't panic. It's not like us. But I think if you ask other companies you are going to see a lot more people, since they are taxed from the point of vesting, there is no ability to put into trust or anything like that. And frankly a lot of us, and I'll just include myself with that, are really getting hit up, which is fine, it's just a way that the law has changed.

Number two, and this one is a tougher one for me, Mark Chatterji, our Chief Financial Officer, he has really put us in a good place in this company and our financial shape. I will tell you, what he has done for this company can't be overstated. As far as I am concerned, I think everybody in Woodside, including the Board, thinks he is the best CFO in Australia. And I know he has built the best financial team of any ASX listed company and we have really, really increased the skill sets thanks to Mark.

I would say that I really respect how he has controlled costs and raised capital for Pluto and really put us into good stead. I will also say that he has been really great on the commercial side. He has built good contracts. He has also prevented me from probably doing some bad deals that I would probably do, so he has really been good.

It's with sadness and happiness I announce that we are going to be losing Mark at the end of the year. He is not going away immediately. But it is sad for Woodside and happy for Mark. Mark has got a growing family and he has got grandparents back in the States and he has got other relatives and he has got friends. He is going to have to get his kids back to where the rest of the family is at.

Now, when I talked to Mark about joining Woodside in 2004, I think he and I were thinking about three years to come in and clean up some issues and fix some things. As you all know I have worked with Mark before Woodside and I knew he could help me out, and he has exceeded all my expectations. And the idea that he will be here almost six years when he leaves is really beyond my wildest dreams.

So he is going to leave Woodside and he has made a lasting positive impact on the company and an impact on me personally and as well as the management team. We will be making the announcement of his replacement later on, but I will tell you he has built a lot of people with certain capability to be CFOs and needless to say that we will be looking to fill his internally first.

So with that, I will turn it over. But I want to congratulate Mark for what he has done. And I just want to say I look forward to working with you in the future. And bottom line is I think that everybody at Woodside will miss you.

Yeah, thanks very much for that, Don. And I imagine everybody that my decision to leave Woodside at the end of 2010 comes as a bit of a surprise. Look, while it might sound trite, I can tell you it was not an easy decision. Woodside is a unique story in the oil and gas industry and I have really enjoyed working with the company and the company's management staff over the years. As Don said, when my family and I arrived at Perth in 2004 we really did not expect to stay as long as we have and now it's getting time for us to go back to the United States at the end of the year.
With that we will sign off on our end and we look forward to seeing a lot of you here in the next couple of days and in the weeks and months to come. Thanks.
Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. Thank you for participating. You may all disconnect.
